Fields.DialogueText: Kapitän, may I have your opinion on something?
Sure, what's up?
Do you think that target is moving too fast to hit?

Fields.MenuText: It must be, since I'm having trouble finding what it is you're talking about. What target?
That depends on what you're trying to hit it with, I think. If we're talking about ramming it, or using an AP shell from one of your primaries? Then yes.
... You mean there's something in this world that you aren't capable of hitting?

Fields.DialogueText: Hmm. It may be too small as well... Thirty degrees to starboard, about twenty meters above the swells.
I wouldn't do that to my gunnery crew, Kapitän. If this exercise was meant for them, I would use a bigger tow banner, and the ship's scout planes instead of my own personal equipment.
You're very kind, Kapitän, but I am not perfect. In this case, however, I would have no trouble hitting the mark because I'm also the one towing the target.
What's it for?
Well, there has been a bit of discussion among the Belles lately, concerning how to determine who is the most accurate.
A floating target, even in rough weather, is not a realistic test, since it was pointed out that if given enough time, any of us should be able to hit the mark.
So I was asked to think of a way we can challenge one another that is fair and safe.
And this is what you've come up with so far. But I'm surprised distance accuracy isn't good enough for bragging rights here...
That gives an unfair advantage to the Belles of larger ships since they carry larger guns.
... Which means more range. Right. What happens if the skeet shooter misses her target and hits the plane instead?
It would be... painful... but not grievously so.
That doesn't sound completely reassuring. I also think you have a couple things to consider about your current setup, Graf Spee.
The target and tow-plane are visible all the time. What's to stop a shooter from anticipating where the target is going to be? That's only slightly more difficult than a floating target.
But if you make things too random, the shooter is at the mercy of your tower's ability and sense of fairness. Is she being equally tough and unpredictable for every shooter?
When you put it that way, I see your point. Thank you for your insight, Kapitän. I'll have to give it further thought later.
Later? Now isn't a good time?
Ja, not anymore... Can you see where I have my plane circling, and what's on the horizon beyond it?
... Morganas. Always Morganas. All right, then, I'll meet you on the bridge.
@BATTLE
All right, let's see... Oh, you mean that flag being towed behind your miniature floatplane?
I thought it more a banner than a flag, but yes, that's the target.
Oh, you aren't wearing your little Ar 196 floatplanes.
There they are!
We can catch them before they hurt Father Raming!
That's the plan.
@BATTLE
I don't think I've seen you hug anyone before, Graf Spee.
I'm just glad to see Father Raming again, Kapitän.
The feeling is mutual, my dear. I'm glad to see you're well!
So, Father, what's taken you so far from home? I know your destination isn't out of our way, but – no offense – seeing to your transport is not a mission I'd expect.
None taken, Kapitän. I just happen to be running an errand for an old friend...
The Secretary of State, His Eminence Cardinal Maglione is an old friend?
Actually, yes. We served in the Vatican Secretariat together during the Great War.
I was moved to return to the life of a small parish priest. His calling led him on a different path. A more... political one.
Political enough to direct a combatant to transport duty, simply so we could meet with you?
The Vatican is an observer member of the League; no different than some of the great powers, like The United States of America. His Holiness has the right to make occasional requests.
His Holiness the Pope...!
... Is aware of you, my child. He's not sure exactly what to make of you, but yes, Pope Pius knows of you. As does the Supreme Sacred Congregation of the Holy Office.
The Inquisition is interested in me?
Very.

Fields.MenuText: I thought the Inquisition was 400 years ago.
The Inquisition is interested in Graf Spee?
I would think they'd be more concerned with the Morganas.

Fields.DialogueText: They go back that far, but they do still exist. They're called the Supreme Sacred Congregation of the Holy Office these days and they're tasked with maintaining the purity of the Faith.
Keenly.
Oh, they are, Kapitän. Very much so. But to date, no Morgana has yet claimed to be Catholic.
Then... practicing my faith is a heresy?
For some, it's considered a mockery.
It's a hotly debated topic. There are some very passionate canon lawyers on your side... present company included.
Still, for now I've been asked to convey to you, Fräulein, that for the time being you are to refrain from any sacrament except absolution. ... Until more is understood.
Would it be poor form to observe that the Lutherans aren't making any Belles I know miserable?
Ja.
Just checking.
And it may be that you're wrong about that, Captain. I think most people whose careers touch on metaphysics are having some challenging discussions these days.
We just have to trust that they're doing so in good faith, and that they'll come to see people like our friend here for what they are.
Thank you, Father. And I will, of course, comply - I don't know that I had the presence of mind to say that before.
"Until more is understood" is rather vague, though. How long is this going to take?

Fields.MenuText: As part of the INPF, we put ourselves in harm's way regularly. If that means five minutes after Graf Spee sinks, we've got a problem.
I'm not unsympathetic, Father, and I realize the mills of God grind slowly, but isn't there something we can do to speed up the process?
I learn something new about Graf Spee every day, and I'm her captain. Please pass on a message to your superiors. He who hesitates is lost.

Fields.DialogueText: I have no doubt there are those in certain orders who would find that outcome nominally regrettable, but not unwelcome.
Unfortunately, no. Especially not with the Vatican landlocked as it is. But have faith... we will resolve this.
Done and well said. The least we can do for is Fräulein Graf Spee is give her a straight, expedient answer.
Personally, I think in this the Good Lord has already made His feelings known by bringing the two of you – and the rest of your crew – together. Speaking of bringing people together...
A package?
From a certain little girl who was most insistent I deliver this to you.
Emily! Father, how is she doing? She's says so much in her letters but shares so little. I can't imagine life in an orphanage is easy.
Well, her marks in school are exemplary and she follows instructions without fail, but among her peers she's also reserved and highly private.
I consider your correspondence with her to be a blessing, Fräulein.
But what I write... my letters are nothing that special, Father.
Anyone could write to her, Graf Spee, but you do. Accept a little praise for being thoughtful, Graf Spee, and carry on as usual.
Understood, Kapitän. ... And thank you both.
@BATTLE
They are also the short-sighted, Kapitän. The faith of a non-human, Salvation-seeking spirit isn't an issue that will go away just by ignoring it.
Have faith, you say. Hoisted by my own petard...
*ALARM*
So, what can we expect from this Inquisition, Father? And why Graf Spee? Vatican or no Vatican, if they think I'm going to stand by and let someone burn my ship at the stake...
Your loyalty is commendable, Kapitän, but it shouldn't come to that. The inquisitor assigned to her case has a unique and unenviable task ahead of him.
As for why you, Fräulein? There are doubtless other Belles among the Protection Fleet that are as moved to be faithful to their beliefs as you are to yours.
However, it's your example that the Holy See learned of first.

Fields.MenuText: You mean Graf Spee is just the most open about what she believes in and adhering to its rules.
I didn't think she was all that loud about being Catholic. How'd the Vatican get wind of her?
She's on the the cutting edge equipment-wise, so I suppose I shouldn't be surprised to learn she leads the way on proceedings, too.

Fields.DialogueText: That's true, Kapitän, but even you must admit that most Belles wouldn't consider it an act of kindness if her crew fetched a local priest to visit.
The exuberance of my flock, I'm afraid. The Holy See looked into why an archdiocese would gift a portrait of their cathedral to an individual Belle.
I believe there's no better Schiffsdame to put forth as a test case, Kapitän.
This should really be no trouble for you two. When the inquisitor comes, he'll just ask some questions and make some observations. That's all.
Hopefully both this guy and the Vatican know that if we get a call to sail, we sail.
I suspect his assignment will be to go where you go until he has what he needs. Don't look so worried, Fräulein. You'll be fine.
I'll try. Well, I guess I'll see to it my guest accommodations are in order for him.
About that. Consider this the two pieces of advice I can provide without tampering with the witness, so to speak. Keep things... temporal, let's say. As little of the supernatural as possible.
And the other piece of advice?
Have a bunk among your lowliest enlisted available, just in case.
@BATTLE
Good point.
Then, I've brought trouble to them and you, Father!
More like the other way around, Fräulein. I was aware of the potential for controversy long before your contrite Quartermaster found my doorstep.
You need to relax, Graf Spee. If one little interview sways this guy one way or the other, then he's coming on board with a bias already in place.
Since you're in it for the long haul, you might as well make a calm first impression. Right?
You are right, Kapitän, but it's easier said than done.
You just need to take your mind off the wait. We haven't had enough months of boredom to go between our moments of terror lately, but I know you're no stranger to routine.

Fields.MenuText: Are you up for a game of Offiziersskat? I think I've got it down enough for a credible rematch...
I'd suggest polishing up, if you weren't already so shiny that you're practically a mirror.
If you need something to do, I could always leave writing our latest action report to you...

Fields.DialogueText: I think you're more than credible, Kapitän, I just can't play at any level below my best.
... You don't think I've gone overboard, have you?
... But then you wouldn't have any routine to occupy your thoughts.
Captain, Miss Graf Spee, the officer of the deck sent me. There's someone dockside who says he has a meeting scheduled with you.
Someone?
Um... Looks like a skinny Friar Tuck, in gray robes.
Show him to the wardroom.
Right away!
Gray robes? I wonder why a Conventual Franciscan was chosen?
We'll know after this battle.
@BATTLE
I know. It means when I do beat you, that I've earned it. Makes the win that much sweeter, in my opinion.
To look your Sunday best? Perish the thought.
Touché.
*ALARM*
Capitaine, I presume?
That's correct. ...And you are?
Father Sebastian Paternoster. I'm the Inquisitor assigned to this case. Let's get right down to business, shall we? How often do you and your crew see the apparition?
Apparition? You mean Graf Spee, right?

Fields.MenuText: You've never met a Belle before, have you.
Apparition? Are you an inquisitor, or an exorcist?
About as often as I see fairies, ghosts and the man in the moon. On the other hand, I work with this ship's Belle frequently.

Fields.DialogueText: No, I have not.
In this case I am in inquisitor, but should circumstances require it, I can call an exorcist in if necessary.
I see. So you don't consider your ship's Belle to be a poltergeist, apparition or ghost. Are you one of those that think the spirit on this ship is a valkyrie?
If you really want to get down to business, why don't I just introduce you to her?
If you can. Where is she...right in front of you?
Standing just behind the bulkhead you came through, actually. Graf Spee makes it a habit to meet new people face-to-face before they see her walk through walls and the like.
How...polite.
Trust me, It is. Come on in, Graf Spee.
Welcome, Father. I am the Belle of the Panzerschiff Admiral Graf Spee.
My apologies for being abrupt, but Captain, the airwaves have just gone berserk! There's been a major skirmish with the nix.
Any orders for us?
Not yet, Kapitän, but based on the reports there are ships in likely need of aid.
All right. Have the officer on duty raise our recall pennant and notify harbor authorities of the potential for our rapid departure, just in case.
Yes, Kapitän. Pardon me, Father.
My word!
Well, that's that. Sorry to cut this short, but it looks like we may be very busy soon.
I handed my letter of transfer to the young man at the dock. If there's anything I can do...
If you have anything you need to retrieve, now's the time to do it.
Due to our vow of poverty, we Franciscans travel light.
Then for the time being, one of my stewards will put you someplace secure... For now, pray.
@BATTLE
Not really. Valkyries in legend aren't usually known for card counting, or a poker face to beat the band.
All alone? I thought I'd find you and Father Paternoster praying together here.
I wouldn't mind that... And I invited him to join me.
But...
*Sigh* He politely declined.

Fields.MenuText: His loss, then.
Well, he is still learning the ropes around here. I'm sure there will be a next time.
Exactly how polite is "politely," Graf Spee?

Fields.DialogueText: I'm sure there will be other opportunities.
And it has been quite busy around here lately. I'm sure you're right, Kapitän.
He was quite courteous, Kapitän! I think, perhaps, that he wants to get to know me through my crew, first.
So if he isn't here with you, what's he up to? Kitchen detail?
Interviewing the crew.
I see. What kind of questions is he asking?
I don't know.
You don't know?
No, Kapitän. ... I wouldn't want to eavesdrop on a confession.
@BATTLE
Well, I guess he wouldn't be the first person we've had on board that was slow getting used to you.
... And now I suppose I cannot.
*ALARM*
Father Paternoster, a word with you please.
Of course, Capitaine. What can I do for you?
Enlighten me. If Graf Spee is the subject of your inquisition, why are you so focused on my crew?
Did the spirit tell you that?
She only told me you are interviewing people. It's my officers who brought it to my attention.
I see. There are many ways to say it, Capitaine, but often I've found one can judge a man by the company he keeps. Shouldn't that also be true for a ship?

Fields.MenuText: Only if the ship gets to choose the company she keeps. The only one on board that she had a say in the matter for is me– everyone else is assigned to her.
Certainly. Just make sure this is the measure of a ship by the sailors who crew her, and not the other way around.
Then I'd say you're wasting your time, sir. I could've told you as soon as you stepped aboard, she has a fine crew.

Fields.DialogueText: Yes, I hear the Belles were very insistent on being allowed to make that choice.
I can see how that conclusion could have been reached.
They are certainly loyal.
My apologies, then. I meant no harm. My intent was to determine how religious this crew is to find out where the spirit's knowledge might have come from.
I think the best person to answer that question would be Graf Spee herself.
*ALARM*
Graf Spee, give me a report!
Air patrol detected a spotter plane, Kapitän.
Do you think it spotted us?
I don't think so, but it's hard to say.
If there's one there's bound to be others. Don't lose that one though, I'll meet you on the bridge.
Right away, Kapitän! ...Pardon me, Father...
Father, you'd best take cover.
... A person, you say, Capitaine? People don't walk through walls.
@BATTLE
*BOOM*
Father Paternoster, you look worried. Is something wrong?
Apparently not, based on your calm, Capitaine. Guns are being fired, yet the battle is won...
Ah, yes... Get used to it, we do a lot of target practice out here.
Target practice?
There's flotsam ahead for us to take advantage of.
Then between the war and the Morganas, your cup must runneth over.

Fields.MenuText: I can have Graf Spee give you a warning the next time, if you'd like...
You know what they say...
Ever been interested in pulling the trigger on a 15cm SK C/28? I could arrange it for you...

Fields.DialogueText: That will not be necessary. I was merely curious.
... Hope for the best and prepare for the worst, hmm? If only those preparations didn't involve becoming adept at causing massive destruction.
Not in the slightest, Capitaine. I was in Bailleul during the Great War... having been on the receiving end of German artillery, I feel no desire to be on the other end of one.
Incidentally, Capitaine, do you know what this flotsam is from, or no?
It's a debris field from a recent sinking.
And we are sailing towards it. There's no chance that there may be survivors among all this wreckage, is there?
After this much time, the chances are remote. But yes, we've seen miracles before. Graf Spee checks our targets beforehand. See those tiny planes?
Now that you mention it, those aren't behaving like birds as I first thought.
*ALARM*
Hmmm. Something must be up for practice to be called off like this.
A pod of dolphins has been sighted inbound. For all crewmembers who cannot prance among them, practice is hereby terminated.
*Sigh* Graf Spee insists she doesn't "prance" with dolphins, but my IO can't resist ribbing her about it.
What does the apparition do, then?
The most graceful game of tag you'll ever see may be a more accurate term for it. Stick around and see for yourself, Father.
If you'll excuse me, I think I need to remind my IO what the consequences are for teasing her...
@BATTLE
Rummy.
Have mercy, Fräulein!
Mercy?
... I think he was hoping to win back more of his money before you got the hang of this one, too.
Yes, and I'm running out of card games that you don't know how to play!
I've warned you before that I play to win...
Aw, don't mind him. He's just sore that his ship is smarter than he is.

Fields.MenuText: Hopefully, he's learned his lesson from the great Professor Graf Spee this time...
I think we're all in the same boat on that one...
... And I'm sore because I didn't think of it first.

Fields.DialogueText: Heh.
Heh.
Heh.
Well, I'm out.
Are you joking? Without a united front we don't stand a chance against her!
I know when to cut my losses.
I guess we're calling it until next payday--
You don't have to stop on my account. You could always get a replacement, like Father Paternoster...
What good would Father patter-over-there be? Franciscans are the poorest of the of the poor. Unless he was willing to bless my hand, there's not much he can contribute to the pot.
... Besides, I already asked him. Given how shocked he was that our Schiffsdame thins our wallets but we still come back for more, I'd say he won't change his mind anytime soon.
... The Nixe are here.
I doubt they would want to play either.
No, but I've found our foe.
@BATTLE
That's quite the crate there, Graf Spee. What's in it?
Something I had Fräulein Lampo build for me. I took your suggestions regarding target competitions to heart, Kapitän.
So I asked her to build a remote control target... something that any Schiffsdame could operate.
That sounds reasonable... But it looks like a pontoon raft with a motor. Unless you're testing parabolic shots to a deck, that looks rather tough...
That could be done, but no, this is only the sled. When it's in position, the target it will carry can be remotely inflated.

Fields.MenuText: Are you sure it was wise to have Lampo build it? It won't fire back or something, will it?
I like where you're going with this. Well done.
And just when I'd become used to the idea of seeing an aerial shooting gallery. Oh well.

Fields.DialogueText: This one won't. I specifically asked her not to add that feature. She did give it ballast tanks though, so it can make shallow dives.
Thank you, Captain. Please keep offering me suggestions. They've been very useful.
As you pointed out it wouldn't be fair, but I will continue to explore it. I may yet find a way to use them in anti-aircraft tests of skill.
So, what does the target look like?
I don't know. Shall I try it?
By all means.
Well then...
*click*
*FSSSSSHHHHH*
WOAH!
AHHH!
W-what is that?
... Is anyone hurt?
This is my fault. I should have specified the size and shape of the target.
I don't think anyone could have predicted something like this. This isn't big, it's HUGE!
I'd say a quarter scale version of Fräulein Pola's hull and superstructure.
... Right. Have her make the next one a Morgana. Target and ship recognition practice and a not-so-subtle insult, all in one package. Sheesh...
@BATTLE
... And if she makes a Mark II?
I can't guarantee for that one.
And... what is it, anyway?
*ALARM*
It shouldn't be for long. I am sorry.
There's no need to apologize, Kapitän.
Next time I see her, I'll ask for advice from Fräulein Hans Lüdemann. She might have ideas about what I overlooked.

Fields.MenuText: She may be a miracle worker but don't sell yourself short, either.
I will anyway. It's not in my nature to see my ship suffer.
I will remember you said that when the chief engineer is sitting at the card table.

Fields.DialogueText: Be that as it may, I should have kept a better eye on its condition, given its importance.
... That's not what you said last time...
I've only managed this far thanks in large part to his efforts, Kapitän. I won't forget.
*ALARM*
So, which Morgana deserves my sympathy for her poor timing?
@BATTLE
Is something wrong, Father?
Aside from those creatures, you mean? I keep hearing... moaning. It's not coming from the infirmary, and I've been assured that everyone is accounted for, but...
*GROAN*
There it is again, do you hear it?
... Yes.
What does it mean?
It means Graf Spee is on her own sick list.
Pardon?
Graf Spee's boilers are rather... sensitive. Her purifier has trouble keeping up even in the best of times.
Until we can reach port to repair it or take on sweeter diesel than we're using now, she's retreated to her hull.
*GROAN*
I don't think she's even aware she's doing that. Hopefully, I can arrange a tow. It may not be dignified, but it beats her heaving over the rail.
Still praying alone?
Ja.
But I am patient, Kapitän. He must have his reasons.

Fields.MenuText: Well I'm not. Complex issue or not, he's got a job to do and I don't feel like he's doing it.
"You're a better man than I am, Gunga Din."
I don't doubt that. Still... has he ever shared those reasons with you?

Fields.DialogueText: ... Well ... It's not my place to judge how he accomplishes this task, but I'll admit I do get the sense he avoids me whenever possible.
That's very kind of you to say, Kapitän. Patience is a virtue. Perhaps this is one of his methods to assess me.
... Well, no... But in his defense, Kapitän, I never asked.
In all this time, has he at least given you absolution?
... No, Kapitän. But he's not obligated to--
And have you asked for it?
...Yes, Kapitän. But--
Then it's time I started an inquisition of my own.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Right after this battle.
You sent for me, Capitaine?
I did. I'd like an update on your progress, Father.
Kapitän... That's not...
Did she put you up to this?

Fields.MenuText: Choose your words carefully, Father. I'm not quite as patient and forgiving as Graf Spee.
No. I am charged with full responsibility for the care and efficiency of this ship and the welfare of all hands. I take that very seriously.
Damn right she did, when she chose me as her captain.

Fields.DialogueText: ... And if I refuse, Capitaine?
I see. And are you saying that you put the care of this... ship... ahead of the welfare of your crew?
So, good or evil, you would defend her?
Look, I don't have time to indulge in verbal sparring matches with you. You're aware there's a war going on, right?
Capitaine, the battle to save souls started long before the first of September.
So there's one standing right in front of you.
-- Is what the Jesuits claim. An entity that claims to be the embodiment of a ship – a work of human hands – contrary to the Dominicans.
Ultimately my mission is to determine what Admiral Graf Spee is. ... So tell me, what are you?
I don't understand--
Neither do I. And I'm still trying to do that, Capitaine.
@BATTLE
I would do with you what I do with any person incompetent at their job and put you off this ship permanently.
Let me put it this way – without a ship we get to swim home, and without a crew the ship doesn't get too far. This matter happens to concern Graf Spee alone, but it does concern my ship.
What are you talking about?
*ALARM*
That doesn't explain why you won't give Graf Spee absolution. I thought she could still have that even during your fact-finding...
That's quite true, but I'm not obliged to give it to this entity. And in light of what I've learned, I'm even less inclined to do so.
Explain.
As an inquisitor, my jurisdiction is limited to the flock of the faithful. This... Admiral Graf Spee...is not one of them.
I'm... I'm not? But--
When were you baptized?
The 30th of June, 1934. The day I was christened and launched. ... I realize it was not a full immersion baptism, but...
I suspected as much. Even supposing that you are what you claim to be, the blessings given to a ship at christening are not the same as those of a proper baptism.
My apologies, Father! I didn't realize the difference. Then, may I formally rectify that error as soon as possible?

Fields.MenuText: You knew that was coming, Father.
Don't look at me. She's the one that asked.
I'll second that, especially the as soon as possible part.

Fields.DialogueText: I suspected it might. If there's one thing I must concede, it's the entity's consistency.
As that is a Sacrament, as soon as possible won't happen as soon as you'd like. If at all.
Here is where this case comes back into my jurisdiction: Whether a priest can initiate this non-human entity into the Faith without performing heresy.
... Father, forgive my intrusion, but... Kapitän, orders addressed to us are coming in.
Then this conversation is tabled, but not finished.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
I still don't understand what the problem is. So Graf Spee didn't dot her 'i'... Isn't there a makeup test, or remedial course or something to put her above board?
I only wish it were that simple, Capitaine. The first problem is, as feminine as 'she' may appear, the entity isn't human.
She's never claimed to be.
And yet "she" appears before us in a human form.
The welders and ship-fitters who built me were human. The men and women who sail me are human. I can think of no other form to take, Father.
Then you still maintain you are this ship. ... That you are not, say, an angel or even a spirit of a saint inhabiting this vessel.

Fields.MenuText: ... Or a demon, as some sort of wolf in the fold. Is that it?
What good would changing her story now do? Would you even believe her?
The Graf Spee I know is too modest to consider herself saint material, no matter how "saintly" a quality that is.

Fields.DialogueText: That is one concern, yes. It just seems... convenient... that one inhuman cohort appears just in time to protect the world from another inhuman cohort.
I'll concede it's true that the burden of proof would be on her... and if proven true, would open up a new, different can of worms.
In all honesty, Father, I can't be sure of what I am.
Then let me tell you what you can become: in these dark times, standing athwart the wickedness that are the Morganas... To those you protect you become a defender. A savior. A symbol.
A god.
@BATTLE
Father, are you insinuating that the Morganas orchestrated their wave of terror and destruction just to allow the Belles to save the day?
Fräulein Kitakami once told me a story from her homeland... about a blue ogre that tricked the children of the village into accepting his friend, a red ogre...
I can safely say Malice is no friend of yours, Graf Spee. Hopefully you've realized by now, Father, the Morganas shoot to kill, and don't surrender.
The end result is still the same. That also doesn't rule out someone or something else from orchestrating all this.
Nevertheless, such a conclusion would placate certain members that find her claimed origins disturbing.
You are too kind, Kapitän. But while it's true that the Lord works in mysterious ways, I only know what I've learned and seen since my christening.
The only title I feel I can claim is Belle of this ship.
Besides Father, you've only met Graf Spee... There are plenty of Belles in the Fleet who couldn't get farther from angelic if they tried.
*ALARM*
I hope you're not looking for guidance in those star charts, Graf Spee.
From an astrological standpoint? No, Kapitän. But, as modern as I am, it is still possible to get lost at sea in a storm.
I wish to be as versed in these charts as possible so that no matter how small the break in the clouds, I can help determine where we are.

Fields.MenuText: Navigation the old-fashioned way. Not a bad skill to have in a pinch.
I'm not going to tell you how to use your free time, and if you want to learn navigation by stars, go ahead. But only if you want to– not because you have to.
Right. ...I'll go put in an order for crows, too. You know, to replace our spotters up in the crow's nest?

Fields.DialogueText: I agree.
I recognise it's not an easy way to navigate, but that it can be done that way fascinates me.
...That will not be necessary, Kapitän.
So this is what you plan to do instead of playing cards with the senior officers.
... Yes, Kapitän.
May I ask why?
Because I don't know how I do it.
You mean besides using talent?
I'm not the only one. And yet I'm still able to compete even with a stiff handicap. What if, as a Belle, I possess something more? Something no human could have.
"Something" you worry you might be using unconsciously, I take it.
Ja. That would put me at an unfair advantage over everyone else. It would be cheating.
Personally I think you're incapable of cheating, but I can't force you to play.
...You could make it an order.
All right, I can force you to play. But that would definitely be cheating. Just remember, this sabbatical is your choice – you still have a chair at the table waiting for you.
I won't forget.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
*ALARM*
Graf Spee, we have a battle to prepare for!
What? Oh, ja... let's go...
@BATTLE
Care to talk about it?
There's not much I can say, Kapitän, save that I could have done better.
Any battle you can sail away from afterwards is still a good battle, especially if you're still sailing under your own power.
You are right of course, Kapitän. I just need to learn from this encounter, and use what I have learned in the future.
... But?
... Father Paternoster's words weigh heavy on me, Kapitän.
When I think of what he said, I can see his point. It would take very little for me to become a golden calf.
When I think of that, of the souls that I could lead astray... am leading astray... I feel as if I am in an ice storm, with my top deck caked in sleet.
I see. And it never occurred to you before this? That if you ran godhood up your flagpole, you would find there are those who'd salute it?
Not quite in those terms, but... I've known from the start there are those who refer to me – to all German Belles – as Walküren.
I have no doubt some Schiffsdamen even encourage it... I prefer the term Belle instead, however. But you mean... it had to be you?
You did pop up and handpick me your captain.
But--!
Graf Spee, with your honor, compassion, and intelligence you could make a decent pass as a deity. Because of your honor, compassion, and intelligence, that's a mantle I know you'd never take up.
That's because I know you. So does everyone else around here. I know you don't have all the answers, but I don't expect you to.
I appreciate that.
As for already "leading people astray," I would think that letting you join the masses as just another sinner looking for guidance and salvation would help nip that in the bud.
But unless someone else pops up and elects me Pope, that's my own personal opinion.
It is an opinion I value highly, Kapitän. Thank you.
So what do you want to do now?
I will take Father Raming's advice. I will be myself, focus on why I'm here, and train for the worst, but I will have faith and hope for the best.
Sounds like a plan to me. Speaking of training--
Ahoy, Schiffsdame. Pod of dolphins sighted off the starboard bow. Stand by to intercept and frolic.
Can I beg you not to arrange for his skivvies to be double-starched this time?
Yes, Kapitän.
Then don't let this affect your next battle. If the stars were in alignment, brush up on your astrology. If not...
That's what training is for.
That's the spirit!
Here I am. What's going on in the crew galley that's important enough to require my presence? Any ideas, Graf Spee?
I just arrived myself, Kapitän.
Kapitän, we asked you here to act as witness. Schiffsdame, this is for you.
I see. Thank you.
Is something wrong, Graf Spee? What does it say?
This is... A letter of challenge?
Yes, Fräulein. Rumor has it that you are currently not playing cards with the senior officers.
That is true.
Then on behalf of the enlisted crew, I'm here to challenge you. It's hardly fair that the officers get to play you and we don't!
I see your point. Well, Graf Spee?
You make it sound as if I should, Kapitän.

Fields.MenuText: Graf Spee, if the enlisted crew is bold enough to invite you to the card table, it would be be impolite not to give them a run for their money.
Absolutely. It's the perfect opportunity to confirm how much of your success is talent and how much is knowing your regulars among the officer corps.
Of course. If the enlisted aficionados believe they can successfully take you on, why not give them the chance to prove it?

Fields.DialogueText: It is also considered impolite to take candy from a baby, so I'm told.
When you put it that way, Kapitän, it wouldn't be a bad idea.
... I suppose it would be unsportsmanlike of me to refuse a formal request to play...
I'll just go get my deck...
Just a minute, Graf Spee. I'd like you to use these, instead.
... A sealed deck? From the Red Cross?
There's more where that came from. They sent me a whole box full.
You don't think that I'm creating an advantage by using my own cards, do you?
No, and I don't want you to think so, either.
Kapitän?
You're worried you might have "something" the rest of us don't, right?
Playing with a fresh deck will help you establish in your own mind that even if you do have 'something,' a familiar deck is not part of it.
... It can't hurt for everyone else at the table to be playing with the deck for the first time, either.
I see. Then I accept this challenge.
*CHEERS*
Fantastic! Then let's not waste a moment--
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
There's no fear of that, Fräulein. You won't find Sunday Bridge club play here.
So, Lampo finally sent you the Morgana target, hm?
You mean this package, Kapitän? Fräulein Lampo sent me the new target a while ago. I tested it and gave her my assessment already.
It's too soon to expect the next prototype from her, however.
So what's in the package?
A plant press. Fräulein Hans Lüdemann was right about Fräulein Parizhskaya Kommuna – she is quite the craftsman.
That's one way to put it. I've seen turrets with less armor than that...
It's entirely possible that is what it's made of – she insisted on repurposing equipment damaged beyond repair.
I see. But even if it's able to stop a 14-inch shell, why do you need a plant press in the first place?
Remember that I was challenged by members of the enlisted crew to a game of cards? There were stakes involved. If I lost, I was to forfeit my cake on Thursday to the winner.
So, do you still have your cake and the right to eat it too?
My serving is still mine. I intend to eat it in the galley with them.

Fields.MenuText: Isn't that a little mean?
Then I'll make sure the galley bakers pull out all the stops for the occasion.
That seems like really low stakes if you ask me. I'd never hear the end of it if you went easier on the enlisted than you do with the officers.

Fields.DialogueText: You think so? Our conversations during the match were pleasant, and I thought I would continue to get to know them better over dessert.
... That sounds rather unsportsmanlike, Kapitän. I thought I'd get to know my fellow players better over dessert, not come across as a sore winner.
That was just the stakes to prevent me from refusing their challenge and forfeiting in the first place.
So, how does the plant press figure in?
For accepting their challenge, the crew thanked me with a book...the first volume of Reichenbachia.
I was struck by the beauty of the flowers it contained, and when I learned how diverse and widespread the orchid family is, I was astounded.
I thought it would be interesting to record the plants that I come across in my travels, but my talents do not lie in illustration or photography.
The press is for preserving actual plants, then...
Is that a problem, Kapitän?
Not collecting samples, no, but you can't go far from your hull, right? That kind of limits the amount of field you can do fieldwork in.
That's true, Kapitän, but I believe I have a solution to that...
@BATTLE
Ah. Then carry on, Graf Spee.
Then you're thinking of making cake with the crew a habit? Now it HAS to be special. Consider it in celebration of the inaugural Thursday Cake with Your Crew.
Ah! Yes, Kapitän.
There was still money on the table. An entrance fee, to ensure only the most serious contenders came forward.
To separate the curious from the competitive, hm? Given there's over a thousand enlisted on board, that makes sense... it would take you weeks to play everyone.
*ALARM*
Father Paternoster, I see we've received orders to transport you to Ostia. Just going to give a status report, or have you reached a decision?
I thought it was obvious why, Capitaine. The apparition stopped praying. Therefore--
Where did you hear that? She still uses her impromptu chapel.
The apparition hasn't asked me to join in prayer for a while now.
Out of respect to your feelings on the matter. She still spends time on her own in quiet, formal prayer.
But I notice the cross is gone.
These days her "chapel" is even more temporary. She takes it down when she's done.
Why?

Fields.MenuText: Graf Spee told me she doesn't want to misrepresent herself. You said so yourself: she may be practicing, but she's not officially Catholic.
That's something you should probably ask for yourself.
I asked her to. I have no problem with her having faith, but I'd rather the crew not feel pressured to follow whatever their ship believes.

Fields.DialogueText: There's no guarantee the aparation's even practicing right.
Out with it already – what's this really about?
What exactly is it? You know that there are some of them that claim to be on the level of divinity...
You're referring to the Kami of the Fleet... the Imperial Japanese Belles.
They... and the Valkyries. On the other hand, there's all of those godless Soviet ships...
Needless to say, Father, each one is an individual.
Individual, but based on their numbers, not unique... and certainly not in existence at the time of Creation.
Neither was the Ark. Noah was commissioned for that one.
If only the Noahs of this time would step forward...
*ALARM*
Looks like somebody stepped forward.
@BATTLE
Not without a knowledgeable observer actually observing one of her prayer sessions, anyway...
... Point taken, Capitaine. Consider this my formal request to be invited to the next prayer session.
I'll let her know.
After all, anyone who did might really be doing it out of worship to her, right?
You are a shrewd one, Capitaine.
All right, crew, there's the Morgana that mauled the merchant ship.
It's our turn to get even. Be ready for combat!
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
How's it looking?
Not well. Her casualties have been transferred to the infirmary and she's back on an even keel, but...
But it's only a matter of time, I take it.
... In her place, I would be striving with every fiber of my being to ensure that I at least saw you and the crew safely to a port.
But now that we're here, I... I think she's convinced that she is too far gone to make it that far.
If she can't sail for us, she would rather slip beneath the waves. My Sigrid Olsen always has been a stubborn one, Kaptein.

Fields.MenuText: Think you can talk some sense into her, Graf Spee?
She's got nothing on me, sir. Now is not the time or place to be throwing in the towel.
Not that I can blame her. It's a shame she didn't wake up. The Fleet could've used a ship with a Belle with her tenacity.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm not sure I can, Kapitän.
Kapitän, I know we have seen ships damaged far worse than this that successfully reached port. But I'm also aware of ships lost from nothing more than open portholes and seacocks.
No man is an island, entire of itself; each is a piece of the continent, a part of the main. If a clod be washed away by the sea, Europe is the less.
Sir, how long should it take you and your crew to transfer over your effects?
It shouldn't take long...
Doctor Geirig sent me specifically to give you the update on your injured, sir... since none of them need my services.
Good to hear. Kaptein, may I take your chaplain here to help? It'll take even less time that way...
My apologies for the confusion, but Father Paternoster isn't my chaplain. He's my inquisitor.
... It's a long story. I have no problem sending him over with you to help, but it needs to be his decision.
I don't want to have to deal with telling the Vatican how I lost one of their inquisitors by sending him onto a sinking ship.
My life is in my Lord's hands. If you think I may be of help to you, then by all means. I will do whatever I can do.
Then come with me.
Are you planning on transferring over her bell, Kapitän?
That had been low on my list of priorities, but now that you mention it... the owner of the company did have it used to baptize his youngest daughter...
How did you--?
This is a terrible thing for me to request, Kapitän, but please... take it last. I get the feeling its fate is her final concern – that once she knew it was secure...
There wouldn't be anything holding her up here.
Then I see no problem making her wait a little longer. Who can say? Maybe she can be persuaded not to go to the bottom long enough for the reinforcements to arrive.
Yes, Kapitän!
Still coming?
Ah, yes. Sorry.
The language barrier?
No, Kapitän, my Norwegian is equal to the task. I don't think she trusts me, though.
I've tried to reassure her that I'm operating in my capacity as a member of the Protection Fleet and will move on as soon as more assistance arrives, but...
I understand. Just do what you can.
Sorry, Frøken.
I know you've done your best.
I know damage control is over there doing everything they can to save her.
Unfortunately, she has made up her mind. She intends this to be her final resting place.
... Damn it.
Each man's death diminishes me, for I am involved in mankind.
... Ask not for whom the bell tolls, it tolls for thee.
Amen.
I'll go get an update on their ETA. Graf Spee, focus on surveillance – I don't want a surprise Morgana doubling back.
Do we need to put into port before Ostia? You look like you could use a visit with a priest.
Do I? Heh. Well, your dossier did note that at sea you act as confessor for... for...

Fields.MenuText: Hold on... The Vatican has a dossier on me?
For her. For my ship's Belle: Admiral Graf Spee.
You can say it...

Fields.DialogueText: Of course. Why shouldn't the Holy See, given the amount of control you have... and the amount of power that you control?
... For la Maîtresse du l'admiral Graf Spee.
... Her.
... I know that the Lord works in mysterious ways, Capitaine. I know that I am meant to be here, on this mission.
What I wish I understood better is what my being here brings that a true naval chaplain does not.
I suppose ship life can come as a culture shock. Still feeling like a stranger in a strange land?
Oui. It seems even a mendicant monk may come to appreciate "C'est un chemin long to Tipperary!"
Perhaps that's your answer, then. By being a fish out of water, you take nothing for granted. You're able to take note of things a seasoned sky pilot would glance over.
Shrewdness and wisdom. It's rare enough to see someone with ample supply of one or the other, Capitaine. Consider yourself blessed to possess both.
That's not what my officers will tell you, Father.
Why is that?
I'm the one that introduced Graf Spee to poker night.
@BATTLE
You needn't worry. Other than Father Raming's observations, the rest is public knowledge.
... Don't act so surprised, Capitaine. I can guarantee that the files on you by other members of the League are far, far larger.
... A little late, but it's a start.
There. Now, was that so hard?
Ships are feminine; even I know that, Capitaine. Admiral Maximilian von Spee, on the other hand...
Robert Surcouf wasn't either.
I know.
*ALARM*
... The cross means this is your prayer time... You're here, aren't you?
... Yes, Father.
You can come out.
Since you were already here, was it necessary to come through the hatch?
I know that my incorporeal state makes you uncomfortable, Father, so rather than appear out of thin air, I decided to leave and re-enter the room the conventional way.
... Father... You asked me before "what are you". Since then, I have given that question much reflection and prayer.
And?
Traditionally, a human soul is a frail thing, ja? Able to be dislodged from the body by simply sneezing.
Yes, and to protect a person's body from possession until their soul returned, you would offer them a blessing.
... Are you claiming to be... what is displaced when this vessel 'sneezes'?
Not a very elegant analogy, even I'll admit, but...
You know, that gives me an idea...
@BATTLE
Per eumdem Christum Dominum nostrum, qui venturus est judicare vivos et mortuos...
*cough*
... You realize that right now my damage control department is having a collective apoplectic fit.
It's just a little incense smoke.
This is more than a little, Father. If I'd known it would be this hazy, I would have organized a pop gas-mask drill.
I can go and fetch yours if you'd like...

Fields.MenuText: Oh, no you don't... you're staying right here until this is over. We're only doing this exorcism once, understand?
I'm fine, just fine... Between the incense and boilers' heat down here I'm busy fighting off a nap, but I'm fine.
Graf Spee, it's kind of hard to project an aura of confidence that nothing is wrong if I'm running around in a gas mask.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm sure it will be easier to shake off the lethargy when we minister to my top deck and superstructure.
I see your point, Kapitän.
A-hem.
My apologies.
... et saeculum per ignem.
So, why is he doing all this and not you, Father?
Father Maynard is a trained and experienced exorcist. I am not.
... And why again is he doing this at all?
To test la Maîtresse du Graf Spee's hypothesis. An exorcist cannot exorcise a victim's soul; only bind and expel what has become attached to it.
Therefore, if she is truly a part of this ship and belongs to it, she will remain. If she's just a confused, human soul that has not moved on yet, this will free her to pass on quietly.
... And if she's a demon, we will find out.
Don't look so grim Capitaine. Consider this a cleansing of the ship on the spiritual level... to protect la Maîtresse, if nothing else.
Ah... Ah...
Achoo!
Gesundheit.
Thank you.
I will not have an act of thoughtfulness on your part be misinterpreted as a need to flee.
Ah, yes... Understood, Kapitän.
*ALARM*
There's that fleet!
Come on, people, we can catch them off guard!
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
Well, Father, I suppose this is where we part ways.
Only for the time being. You don't get to be rid of me that fast, Capitaine. La Maîtresse hasn't given me her letter yet.

Fields.MenuText: That's fine, Father. Just as long as I'm not the one that makes you late to see the Pope...
I thought pen-pal correspondence started when the correspondent was more than 10 yards away from the corresponder.
Yes, I could... if you hadn't finally started using terms like "her" and " La Maîtresse".

Fields.DialogueText: What makes you think a simple inquisitor sees the Pope?
While I have given her an address for further correspondence, this is more a... Let's just say, letter of introduction.
You sailors and your pride for your ships... Ahem. I will mind my manners in the future, Capitaine.
I'm sorry for the delay, Father. Here you are – my formal request.
May I? ... Yes... yes. This will do.
Daisy Brigade, final call. I repeat.
Ah... that's for me.
... Daisy Brigade?
Graf Spee recently decided to take up amateur botany. Her range is limited to the docks, though, so she's been using her poker winnings to "hire" people to go into the field for her.
It gives her victims a way to earn some of their money back.
Only some?
I tithe first.
Ah. Still... "Daisy Brigade"?
They solemnly pledge to either come back with plants or remain pushing up the daisies.
Hopefully they bring you back more than one sample, pressed flowers make lovely bookmarks. Bonjour, Capitaine. La Maîtresse du Graf Spee, Bonjour.
Rome wasn't built in a day, Graf Spee. It's a start, at least.
"Simple" inquisitor? If the Pope saw fit to pull strings and put you on my ship for this little mission of yours, I see every reason why the debriefing would be directly to him.
Ultimately, I go before the tribunal on the matter to give my report. But if His Holiness took an interest, he could indulge his curiosity sooner than that, yes.
